entry.title: Re: Evaluate my Internal Tool Against Syniti ADDM ( (SAP...
entry.content:
Hi @karthik1gobburu 

Thank you for your question.

  1. Yes, Syniti ADMM can be used with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

Syniti‚Äôs Advanced Data Migration and Management (ADMM) solution is officially SAP Premium Certified and recognised as SAP‚Äôs partner data migration tool of choice for all S/4HANA transition scenarios, including RISE with SAP and Public Cloud Syniti solutions accessing SAP ECC and SAP S/4HANA: What is permitted?

In Public Cloud, it supports data migration by connecting to the Migration Cockpit‚Äôs HANA Cloud staging database and extracting data through OData services, often via Syniti Connect with Boomi for OData extraction skthelp.syniti.com.

  1. Can your internal migration tool replace Syniti ADMM?

From the standpoint of SAP-certified migration paths in Public Cloud, the SAP Migration Cockpit (pre-delivered by SAP) and SAP-certified partner tools (like Syniti ADMM) are the supported and endorsed approaches.

An internally developed tool cannot officially replace Syniti ADMM in Public Cloud migration scenarios because:

  • It is not SAP-certified as a solution extension.
  • Its use would fall outside SAP‚Äôs supported migration framework for Public Cloud.
  1. In What Parameters Does Syniti ADMM Add Value?

When evaluating whether your internal tool can match Syniti ADMM, consider how Syniti fares across the following key migration criteria:

  • SAP Certification and endorsement for Public Cloud migrations.
  • Connectivity options: Syniti integrates with Migration Cockpit staging DB and extracts via approved APIs (e.g., OData via Boomi)  Connecting to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Migration methodology: Syniti uses a ‚ÄúData First,‚Äù knowledge-driven approach, with automation, repeatability, and quality controls  SAP S/4HANA Data Migration
  • Support and governance: As a certified solution, Syniti is backed by SAP support and roadmap alignment.

If you will like to position your internal tool, you will need to evaluate how it aligns on these parameters, even though a full replacement of Syniti ADMM in Public Cloud is outside SAP‚Äôs supported landscape.

 

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Stop the Buzzword Circus: Real Impact Starts with Mobile
entry.content:
Let's be blunt. The term "digital transformation" has become a playground for charlatans, peddling expensive, multi-year projects with dismal success rates ‚Äì often exceeding 70% failure. This isn't strategic evolution; it's "Buzzword Bingo," designed to extract capital without delivering tangible value. Many organizations dive in without a clear strategy, leading to wasted resources and frustration.

Meanwhile, the cost of clinging to outdated manual processes is staggering. American employees waste over nine hours a week on data entry, costing businesses a hefty $28,500 per employee annually. This isn't just about salary; it‚Äôs about errors ‚Äì humans make 100-400 errors per 10,000 entries compared to the near-perfect accuracy of automated systems [8, 9]. These errors cascade into financial losses and operational bottlenecks.

The solution? A pragmatic approach centered on the mobile-first advantage. By leveraging smartphones and tablets for instant digital intake ‚Äì think scanning forms with intelligent document processing (IDP) ‚Äì we eliminate manual errors and unlock real "low-hanging fruit." This isn't about grand transformations; it‚Äôs about targeted digitalization that delivers immediate ROI. For example, field service apps using mobile data collection can boost efficiency and reduce errors by up to 70%. This isn't a futuristic fantasy; it‚Äôs a proven strategy for tangible results.

entry.title: Re: is there any relationship between an account assignme...
entry.content:
When you enter the account assignment category (e.g., K for cost center), SAP re-evaluates the tax code based on the access sequence defined in the tax condition type (typically TTX1).

Common Access Sequence fields are Material, Plant, Account Assignment Category, Region & Origin Country. So if your condition table includes Account Assignment Category as a key field, the system may override the PIR tax code (V3) with a new one (V1) based on the combination of material, plant, and account assignment.

To ensure that V3 (10%) remains the default tax code even after entering account assignment, you can:

1. Review and Adjust the Condition Table
Go to SPRO ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Taxes ‚Üí Define Access Sequences. Check the access sequence used by TTX1. If it includes Account Assignment Category, either remove it from the access sequence, or create a new condition record for Account Assignment Category = K with tax code V3.

2. Create Specific Condition Records
Use transaction FV11 to create tax condition records for Material + Plant + Account Assignment Category = K ‚Üí Tax Code = V3.

3. Check Tax Indicator in Material Master
Ensure the Tax Indicator for Material is set correctly in the material master (Purchasing view). This influences tax determination when PIR is not used.

A Best Practice tip is if you want consistent tax behavior regardless of account assignment, simplify your access sequence to exclude fields that cause variability (like AAC). But if you need different tax codes for different AACs, then condition records must be maintained accordingly.

entry.title: Interactive Debugging in SAP Callidus Advanced workflow
entry.content:
Hello All,

I am working with SAP Callidus (SAP Commissions) Advanced Workflow and facing difficulties with debugging options.

Currently, I am relying on logger.info statements to print variable values or outputs from methods. While this helps to some extent, it is not efficient when workflows and scripts become large and complex.

What I am looking for is something similar to the SAP ABAP/Eclipse debugger, where we could:

  • Set breakpoints in the workflow script

  • Inspect available variables, objects, classes, or methods at runtime

  • Step through the workflow execution to see what events are triggered and in what sequence

My questions are:

  1. Is there any way (official or unofficial) to perform interactive debugging with breakpoints in Callidus Advanced Workflow?

  2. Are there tools, techniques, or plugins that can make debugging easier than just using logger.info statements?

  3. How can we explore the list of available classes and methods that can be used in workflow scripting? Is there documentation or a way to introspect them?

  4. What are the best practices you recommend for troubleshooting and debugging in Advanced Workflow?

Debugging without visibility into available classes and methods is proving very challenging, so any recommendations, tips, or even workarounds would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks for your help and support.

#Advanced workflow, #Callidus

Thanks, Sateesh

entry.content:
My first reaction was "of course, those widgets take up space unnecessarily" but when I looked at a blog without the widgets on my desktop with a large screen, I realized how hard it is to read text that runs over a such a long line. The widgets actually ensured that that the lines could never be too long.  
So maybe the behavior (display widgets or not) could be dynamic depending on current window size, with widgets always hidden when reading on mobile devices?

entry.title: Re: Down payments for Non-Trade Supplier are not applicab...
entry.content:
Why this happens is because, in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Trade Suppliers are typically linked to purchase orders and goods receipt processes. Non-Trade Suppliers are used for indirect procurement or services, often without a PO. The Manage Down Payment Request app relies on purchase order integration and certain business catalogs that are not activated for Non-Trade scenarios. This is why the app doesn‚Äôt allow you to process down payments for Non-Trade Suppliers.

Below are some workaround options:

1. Use Supplier Invoice Request App
You can manually create a down payment request for Non-Trade Suppliers using the Supplier Invoice Request Fiori app. This bypasses the PO dependency and allows you to initiate the payment manually.

2. Post Down Payment Directly
If the invoice request route is too restrictive, you can use Post Outgoing Payments app to manually post a down payment. Then clear it against the final invoice when it arrives.

3. Custom Workflow or Extension
If this is a recurring business need, consider building a custom tile or workflow using SAP BTP or In-App Extensibility to replicate the down payment logic for Non-Trade Suppliers. This can include approval flows and audit tracking.

As a Best Practice suggestion, if your organization frequently processes down payments for Non-Trade Suppliers, it may be worth reviewing whether these suppliers could be reclassified or whether a hybrid process (e.g., dummy PO for tracking) could be introduced to align with standard functionality.

entry.title: Re: Production Process in SAP S4 HANA Public Cloud Edition
entry.content:
Hello,

To prevent you get an additional and unwanted R100 on stock, you can use the app app 'Production Order without Material - Create' (trx. CO07). Here R01, R102, and R103 will be consumed, but there will be no goods receipt of R100, unlike with a regulare production order (Create Production Order - Co01).

In the end, the choice of which process works best for you is up to you (our your client). The GI and GR workaround is clean and simple, but doesn't support capacity planning, costing, etc. which the by-product scenario does.

They're both workarounds (since S/4 Public Cloud does not support a native disassembly process) and the choice is up to you which suits your case best.

Kind regards,
Rick

entry.title: Announcing the VNSG SAP BTP Hackathon
entry.content:
Following successful collaborations with SAP User Groups worldwide, we are pleased to announce that the SAP BTP Hackathon initiative is coming to the Netherlands. VNSG and SAP are partnering to host the first-ever VNSG SAP BTP Hackathon in the country

In a nutshell:

  • This event is open to all SAP customers, including both VNSG members and non-members
  • Customers can nominate a use case that demonstrates how they leverage SAP BTP capabilities to innovate and optimize their business processes
  • Coaches and the organization team will then select the participating teams to further develop their use case
  • Up to 3 finalists will showcase their solution during the Demo Jam at the VNSG and SAP annual event in March 2026, with the chance to win some cool prizes

Ronald Schippers, managing director of the VNSG, shared his thoughts on the event during preparation:

The VNSG SAP BTP Hackathon is the opportunity for our members to showcase their creativity and innovative strength through collaboration. It offers the chance to work together with SAP to transform innovative ideas into tangible solutions that make an impact ‚Äî powered by SAP BTP.

At VNSG, our core values are ‚Äúcommunity‚Äù and ‚Äúknowledge sharing.‚Äù That‚Äôs why this hackathon is not just about competition; it‚Äôs about building connections, fostering personal and professional growth, gaining new insights, and bringing innovation to life together ‚Äî all while having a great time.

I warmly invite all our VNSG members to seize this opportunity: to innovate, to learn from SAP‚Äôs global and local experts, and to experience the true impact of innovation and community.

We can‚Äôt beat this intro, so we are not even going to try üòÄ

 

Details

SAP BTP is THE platform to integrate and extend SAP applications. In simple terms, if you were an artist, SAP BTP would be the colors and brushes you use to create your ‚Äúmasterpiece‚Äù or provide the needed ‚Äútouch ups‚Äù to existing paintings, in a way that looks and feels as if the original artist had done it.

It‚Äôs used by customers, partners and SAP to innovate and optimize business processes while leveraging the latest and greatest cloud technology. From SAP Integration Suite to SAP Build to SAP HANA Cloud and everything in between, if your stakeholders have a question, SAP BTP is the answer.

The SAP BTP hackathon challenge will showcase how customers can use SAP BTP to adapt and optimize their business processes. But that‚Äôs not all!

Participants will also benefit from in-depth enablement sessions led by SAP product experts to help them through the ideation and build phases.

The participating customers, those who have had their use case selected for the SAP BTP hackathon, will also have access to expert coaches during their build phase. Coaches are there to make sure ‚Äúno use case is left behind‚Äù üòâ

Once the build phase is completed, customers will pitch their use case to a jury of SAP experts. The jury will choose 3 finalists based on different criteria, like business relevance, SAP BTP usage, innovation and vision, that will go on to demo their use case in front of a live audience at the annual VNSG and SAP event.

To show off your efforts, participating team members will get special badges added to their SAP Community profile. So, if you are not yet an SAP Community member, what are you waiting for?

 

To all NL SAP Customers

Don‚Äôt miss this unique opportunity to participate in the SAP BTP hackathon!

In short:

  1. Submit your use case üëâüèª here by October 15
  2. (Selected customers) Build your prototype and prepare a short 5 to 10 min video including the business value, solution diagram and demo by December 10
  3. Get ready to pitch your demo in February 2026 in front of a panel of experts [exact dates to be confirmed]
  4. (Finalists) Compete in the Demo Jam in March 2026 at the VNSG and SAP annual event

In case you still need convincing, let me reiterate some of the perks:

  • Attend SAP BTP enablement sessions led by SAP experts for inspiration and knowledge.
  • Engage with the SAP ecosystem and get special badges to display on your profile. Don‚Äôt forget to create an account in the SAP Community
  • Get direct access to SAP BTP coaches to support you during your build phase.
  • Expand your SAP BTP knowledge and bridge the gap between business and IT.

In case you have any question on the event, please drop a comment below üëáüèª

 

Conclusion

Don‚Äôt be shy and join the fun. Brainstorm with your teams and bring your innovative ideas to life with SAP BTP üòâ

entry.title: Re: calculate tax checkbox per line item within FB60
entry.content:
To your question, "Is the ‚ÄúCalculate Tax‚Äù checkbox in FB60 a SAP standard update?", the answer is YES, the ‚ÄúCalculate Tax‚Äù checkbox in line items of FB60 is part of the SAP standard update in S/4HANA. This enhancement was introduced to give users more granular control over tax calculation at the line-item level, especially in scenarios involving manual tax entry, gross/net methods, or mixed tax codes.

In ECC 6.0, tax calculation was typically handled at the header level or via implicit logic. S/4HANA has improved this by allowing users to explicitly toggle tax calculation per line item, which aligns with the broader user experience improvements and financial accuracy goals of the new platform.

So in your case, this checkbox is not a company-specific add-on, but a standard SAP UI enhancement.

To your next question, where to find out, SAP doesn‚Äôt always highlight minor UI changes in broad release notes, but there are several reliable sources to track these updates:

One is SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library
Next, SAP Help Portal  Portal. Choose your S/4HANA version (e.g., 2022, 2023) and navigate to Finance ‚Üí Accounts Payable ‚Üí Vendor Invoice Processing. Look for ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs New‚Äù or ‚ÄúFeature Scope Description‚Äù documents.

To streamline your analysis:

  • Create a change log matrix comparing ECC vs S/4HANA screens.
  • Tag each change as ‚ÄúSAP Standard‚Äù or ‚ÄúCustom‚Äù based on findings.
  • Use SAP GUI scripting or Fiori trace tools to identify backend objects tied to UI elements‚Äîthis helps confirm if a field is standard.

entry.title: Re: Make Custom Fields Read Only - S/4Hana Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Philipp,

thank you for your question.

Switching a custom field between editable and read-only in S/4HANA Public Cloud is unfortunately not a simple, one-click setting. The answer depends on a couple of important factors:

  • Type of custom field
    ‚Äì whether it was created as a Key User Custom Field in the Custom Fields app, or as a Developer Extensibility Custom Field via ABAP development tools.

  • UI and OData technology of the standard app
    ‚Äì whether the Fiori application is based on SEGW OData services, or on OData services exposed with service binding (RAP model).

These dimensions influence whether and how you can make a custom field mandatory, read-only, or invisible (either statically or dynamically).

The following blog provides the general overview and step-by-step guidance on how to determine to which category your app belongs and what options you have:
Custom Fields in S/4HANA: How to control field properties like mandatory, read-only, and visibility

For your specific case ‚Äì Manage Sales Orders (Version 2) ‚Äì this is a Fiori application based on OData service C_SALESORDERMANAGE_SRV, which belongs to the service binding / RAP category. This means field control is only supported if the app has been enabled for it.

Here is the detailed blog relevant for your scenario (Fiori UI based on OData services with service binding):
Key User Custom Fields in Fiori UIs based on OData services exposed with service binding

 

Please have a look, and if you‚Äôd like, I can walk you through the specific steps for your case.

Kind regards,
Diana

entry.title: Re: is there any relationship between an account assignme...
entry.content:
Hello @0uTY 

Indeed, in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the account assignment category is essential for determining the tax code linked to a Purchase Order.

Understanding this influence is crucial, and here‚Äôs why you observe this behaviour:

Default Tax Code Logic,
Tax code proposal in PO comes from multiple sources:

    1. Purchasing Info Record / Material Master if available
    2. Configuration in SSCUI / CBC for tax determination, such as a country, tax procedure, and tax condition records
    3. Account Assignment Category and  GL Account ‚Üí When you enter account assignment category K (Cost Center), the system derives the consumption GL account from account determination. That GL account may have different tax determination logic assigned to linked condition records, which is why your tax code Changes from V3 (10%) to V1 (5%).

Why does it change:
For consumable POs, the system meticulously validates tax determination against the expense account, not only the material or PIR. This thorough process ensures the accuracy of the tax code proposal after assigning the account assignment category.

How to keep 10% V3 as default:

    1. Check the tax determination configuration in CBC ‚Üí SSCUI 101016 to Define Tax Code Determination Rules for country-specific settings.
    2. Review condition records transaction type Set Tax Codes per Account Keys assigned to the GL accounts that are triggered by account assignment K.
    3. If necessary, it's crucial to maintain the manual default tax code in the Purchase Info Record or override it manually in the PO if your business allows.

So yes, there is an indirect relationship: when you pick an account assignment, the system re-derives account determination and applies the tax code accordingly

SAP Documentation Reference:

  • KBA ‚Äì Tax Code Determination in Purchase Orders (S/4HANA Cloud)
  • Scope Item J45 ‚Äì Procurement of Direct Materials-SAP Learning 
  • Maintain Condition Record-SAP Help  

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: E-mail notification for PR approval not working
entry.content:
Some key areas you need to check are

1. Workflow Email Step Configuration
Go to SWDD and open the workflow template (e.g., WS20000077 for PR approval). Check if there's an explicit email step (Send Mail) configured after the approval task. If not, you‚Äôll need to add a Send Mail step that triggers when the PR is ready for approval. SAP workflows don‚Äôt send emails automatically unless a mail step is defined.

2. Notification Settings in SWNCONFIG
Use transaction SWNCONFIG to configure Extended Notifications. Ensure the scenario for PR approval is active and includes Recipient type (user ID), Notification channel (email) and Schedule job to send notifications (SWN_SELSEN)

3. Background Job SWN_SELSEN
Check if the job SWN_SELSEN is scheduled and running. This job is responsible for sending out email notifications for workflow events.

4. SCOT Configuration (SAPconnect)
Go to SCOT and verify email domain is correctly configured. SMTP node is active. No errors in the send queue (SOST).

5. User-Specific Settings
In SU01, confirm email address is in the correct format. Communication method is set to INT (Internet). Also check SO16 and SO13 for default communication settings.

6. Fiori Notification Channel
Fiori notifications are separate from email. If you're using SAP Fiori Launchpad notifications, ensure the Notification Hub is active. The user has subscribed to the relevant notification types.

Finally, and importantly, if you want both Fiori notifications and email alerts, you‚Äôll need to configure both channels independently. SAP doesn‚Äôt automatically mirror Fiori notifications to email unless explicitly set up via workflow or extended notification.

entry.title: Territory Deletion in SAP Sales Cloud V2 (Restricted Release)
entry.content:
Territories in the system support logical deletion.

Logical deletion means the territory isn‚Äôt physically removed from the system. Instead, it is marked as deleted. This allows the system to keep the record for reference, especially if the territory is linked to other entities.

A few things to keep in mind:

  • Once a territory is deleted, the action cannot be undone.

  • Only child territories can be deleted. If a territory has its own child territories, you must delete those first before deleting the parent.

  • The IDs of deleted territories cannot be reused.

In short, deleting a territory marks it as deleted but keeps it in the system to preserve consistency.

entry.title: Re: Batch Specific UoM conversion functionality not worki...
entry.content:
Some of the potential root causes beyond Configuration

1. Incorrect Characteristic Value Interpretation
Even if the characteristic BASE_M_TO_CONV_PC is correctly maintained, SAP might be misinterpreting it due to decimal format issues (e.g., 5.5 being read as 2.75 due to localization settings or rounding logic). Unit conversion factor misalignment in the material master or class assignment. Check the internal table values during GR posting (e.g., via debugging or transaction MB51) to see what conversion factor is being picked up.

2. Batch Class Assignment Conflict
If multiple classes are assigned or if the batch class is not properly linked to the material. SAP may default to a fallback conversion or ignore the batch-specific value. Use CL30N to confirm that the batch class is uniquely assigned and active for the material.

3. GR Posting via MIGO vs. Other Transactions
Sometimes, the behavior differs depending on whether you're posting via MIGO, CO11N, MB1A / MB31. Test the same batch in different posting transactions to see if the issue is transaction-specific.

4. Recent System Patch or Note Implementation
If this issue started suddenly, it‚Äôs possible that a support package or SAP Note was applied that altered the conversion logic. A custom enhancement or BAdI was introduced or modified. Check with your BASIS or ABAP team for recent transports or OSS notes applied in the system.

One diagnostic suggestion from my side to isolate the issue:

  • Create a test material with a simplified setup (one batch, one class, one characteristic).
  • Post a GR for 10 PC and observe the base UoM conversion.
  • If it works correctly, the issue is likely data-specific or enhancement-related.

entry.title: Realizing AI‚Äôs Potential in and Through SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Realizing AI‚Äôs Potential in and Through SAP Integration Suite 

AI is reshaping how enterprises approach integration, simplifying complex processes, reducing manual effort, and unlocking new levels of agility. In SAP Integration Suite, AI is more than just a trend: it is both a set of powerful capabilities enhancing integration today, and a key enabler for intelligent, connected systems in the future.  

  • AI in Integration Suite ‚Äì Intelligence is embedded directly into the product to enhance developer productivity, improve operational efficiency, and accelerate time to cloud through features like flow generation and optimization, anomaly detection, and intelligent troubleshooting and monitoring. 
  • Integration Suite for AI ‚Äì SAP Integration Suite also plays a vital role in enabling next-generation AI scenarios. It acts as the integration foundation for orchestrating autonomous, context-aware agents and supporting seamless interaction between AI systems and enterprise landscapes, backed by the governance and scalability that modern businesses need. 

This blog offers a practical overview of SAP Integration Suite‚Äôs evolving AI capabilities, highlighting how AI is embedded in SAP Integration Suite today, how it maps to key integration needs, and how it enables customers to build toward an AI-augmented future. 

 

AI in Integration Suite: Embedded Intelligence in Action

AI is not an isolated feature in SAP Integration Suite, instead, it‚Äôs woven into the platform to enhance how integrations are designed, built, and operated. Our embedded AI capabilities focus on delivering real, day-to-day value across two core dimensions: 

  • Improve developer productivity
  • Enhance operational excellence

Here‚Äôs how embedded intelligence is making an impact in these areas: 

Improve Developer Productivity 

Designing integrations can be time-consuming, especially when dealing with complex mappings, unfamiliar systems, or writing custom scripts to handle specific logic. SAP Integration Suite embeds AI to streamline this process and help developers move faster with greater confidence. 

  • iFlow Creation
    Developers can now generate integration flows simply by describing the scenario in natural language. This generative AI capability interprets the intent, assembles a draft iFlow with relevant flow steps, and gives developers a strong starting point, and significantly accelerating the design phase. Future enhancements are expected to include automatic generation of mappings, scripts, and other artifacts to further streamline the process. Check the roadmap for new updates. 

 

  • Script Optimization
    Generative AI in SAP Integration Suite can help developers refine Groovy and JavaScript scripts by analyzing code in real time and suggesting best-practice optimizations. These recommendations reduce the need for manual tuning, streamline the coding process and help maintain high performance and quality from the outset.
  • Integration Advisor
    Integration Suite is one of the first iPaaS to embed AI into capabilities for supporting B2B scenarios. Integration Advisor uses a machine learning-based, global knowledge pool to propose mappings between source and target structures. By learning from industry standards and past implementations, it dramatically reduces the time and effort required to configure B2B and A2A integrations, especially in complex message transformation scenarios.
  • Flow Step Recommendations
    When developers build integration flows, AI recommends the next logical flow step, such as a Groovy script or End Message, based on usage patterns. This intelligent guidance accelerates the flow creation process, minimizes trial-and-error, and supports consistent design quality across teams.

Together, these capabilities significantly reduce repetitive tasks, speed up development, and help teams deliver high-quality integrations more efficiently, regardless of their experience level. 

 

Enhance Operational Excellence 

Operational reliability is critical for scalable, enterprise-grade integration. SAP Integration Suite embeds AI to help teams proactively monitor, maintain, and optimize their integration landscapes, reducing manual troubleshooting and improving long-term performance. 

  • API Anomaly Detection 
    Leveraging machine learning, the platform continuously monitors integration flows and APIs to detect unusual patterns, such as latency spikes, increased error rates, or unexpected traffic surges. This helps teams identify and address issues before they impact business processes, improving response time and reducing downtime. 

 

  • API Volume Prediction
    AI models analyze historical usage patterns to forecast, providing two distinct insights: one on historical usage trends and the other on predicted future volumes. The dual view helps developers and operations teams stay ahead of peak loads and avoid capacity-related disruptions, ensuring both long-term planning and real-time operational awareness.
  • Script Optimization
    Generative AI analyzes custom Groovy or JavaScript scripts used in integration flows, identifying potential performance bottlenecks or inefficiencies. It then recommends optimized versions of the code, enabling developers to improve execution quality without deep manual debugging or rewriting.

By embedding these intelligent capabilities, SAP Integration Suite supports a more proactive, data-driven approach to integration operations, allowing teams to deliver higher reliability with less overhead. 

 

Integration Suite for AI: Enabling the Next Generation of Intelligent Automation

As the enterprise landscape evolves, agentic AI is emerging as a new class of autonomous systems that can reason, interact, and execute tasks on behalf of users. This shift is driving demand for more adaptable and intelligent integration backbones. To function effectively, these AI agents must be able to connect with enterprise systems, orchestrate business logic, access data, and execute workflows securely and reliably. This is where SAP Integration Suite becomes essential. It not only embeds AI to optimize development and operations, but also plays a foundational role in enabling agentic AI by providing the connective fabric that links intelligent agents with business applications and services. 

Across the industry, we‚Äôre seeing a growing push toward agent-centric automation, from AI copilots to autonomous digital workers, and integration is the linchpin that determines whether these agents can truly act in context. SAP Integration Suite helps enterprises bridge this gap with built-in capabilities that simplify how AI agents discover, consume, and govern enterprise integrations. 

Here are two ways it already supports this shift: 

  • AI Adapter
    The AI Adapter enables seamless communication between SAP Integration Suite and generative AI services, provided by SAP‚Äôs AI Core or third-party providers like OpenAI. With minimal configuration, developers can embed AI capabilities, such as text generation, summarization, or classification, directly into integration flows. This makes it easier to enrich payloads with contextual insights, automate decision logic, and integrate AI-driven functionality within a governed framework. By removing the need for custom scripting or API handling, the AI Adapter boosts developer efficiency and expands the scope for advanced AI-powered use cases. 
  • AI-Powered Content Recommendations in Business Accelerator Hub
    To help agents and developers access the right integration assets quickly, the SAP Business Accelerator Hub features Joule for natural language search. Instead of browsing manually, users (or agents in the future) can ask questions like ‚ÄúHow do I connect SAP S/4HANA to Salesforce?‚Äù and receive tailored recommendations across integration flows, APIs, and templates. This AI-driven discovery process reduces time to integration and enhances reusability, which is the key requirement for agent-based automation where responsiveness and adaptability are critical.

 

Where We‚Äôre Heading 

The evolution of AI in SAP Integration Suite is accelerating, expanding beyond foundational productivity and monitoring features into more adaptive, intelligent, and autonomous integration experiences. 

On the embedded AI front, we‚Äôre advancing how integrations are designed, optimized, and managed. Expect more powerful capabilities for automating integration development and API operations, along with intelligent migration from legacy systems like SAP Process Orchestration. These innovations are designed to further boost developer efficiency, reduce operational overhead, and reduce time to cloud. 

At the same time, SAP Integration Suite is evolving to support agent-driven automation. As part of this direction, we plan to enhance the API Management to allow AI systems to interact with enterprise tools and data. This will enable more dynamic, context-aware automation, built on a foundation of governance, scalability and future readiness. 

In the upcoming blogs, we‚Äôll explore each of the two directions in depth, highlighting real-world use cases, customer stories, and innovations that are redefining integration in the era of AI.

entry.title: Re: Entry xxxxxxx does not exist in J_1BTXJUR (check entry)
entry.content:
Some key areas to recheck

1. Jurisdiction Code Format
Ensure that the jurisdiction code in your document is exactly formatted as it appears in J_1BTXJUR‚Äîno extra spaces, leading zeros, or case mismatches. SAP is strict about matching the internal format of the jurisdiction code.

2. Address Determination Logic
Even though ME23N shows the correct address, SAP might be deriving the jurisdiction code from a different source during invoice posting (e.g., vendor master or plant address). Use transaction SE37 to debug the function module J_1B_GET_JURISDICTION to see how the code is being derived.

3. Missing Link in Configuration
Check if the jurisdiction code is assigned to the correct tax region and tax type in J_1BTXJURT. Also verify that the tax code used in the invoice is linked to the correct jurisdiction group in J_1BTXISS.

4. Document Origin
If the invoice is being posted via MIRO, FB60, or an interface (like IDoc), the jurisdiction code might be missing or malformed in the payload. Use transaction SOST or IDoc monitoring (WE02) to inspect the raw data.

To narrow down the issue, try posting a test invoice manually using FB60 with the same vendor and tax code. If it works, the issue is likely interface-related or data-specific. If it fails, the problem is likely in the jurisdiction setup or derivation logic.

entry.title: Actual Costing in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Actual Costing is available in SAP Cloud ERP (S/4HANA Cloud, public edition) with the scope item 33Q. It valuates all goods movements (procurement, manufacturing, stock transfers, subcontracting, etc.) and collects any incurred variances for your materials within a period and calculates their actual prices, which are usually more accurate than standard prices (S-price) and moving average prices (V-price) in reflecting actual costs of the products.

At period end, the actual prices are also used to revaluate your consumption, e.g. COGS (cost of goods sold), and period-end inventory. Valuation at actual cost is not only helpful but also legally required in some countries/regions as your financial statements, such as Profit & Loss statement and Balance Sheet, can be updated with the actual costing results.

Actual Costing helps you gain real-time insights into business performance and make informed decisions, especially in industries or organization with big fluctuations in raw material prices or volatile production processes.

Now, let‚Äôs look at a simplified example to understand how Actual Costing works:

Example Process

In this example, various transactions are involved to demonstrate how price variances are collected from purchase of the lower-level material and production of the finished goods, how the variances are then allocated to cost of sales and remaining inventory, and what revaluation journal entries are posted to reflect the real product profitability.

Let‚Äôs walk through each step to see how data is processed in Actual Costing:

1. Create a Purchase Order

Company code 1210 has EUR as its local currency (company code currency). The raw material RM124 has a standard price of 0.35 EUR/PC in plant 1210 in period 008/2025 as shown in the material master record below:

A purchase order (4500000253) is created, ordering 100 pieces of RM124 with a net price of 0.50 USD/PC from a foreign supplier.

Note that the total PO price of 50 USD is converted into 40.39 EUR with the exchange rate 1.23794 effective at PO creation. This leads to a price difference of 5.39 EUR between PO price and standard price (40.39 ‚Äì 35.00 = 5.39 EUR).

2. Receive Goods for the Purchase Order

Following goods receipt of 50 PC of RM124 into inventory, you can see the price difference is collected in the Actual Costing app ‚Äì Material Price Analysis (CKM3N):

By selecting the goods receipt line and choose Source Document, you will find the price difference of 5.39 EUR is debited as a net loss in a P&L account under transaction key PRD in the Accounting document:

3. Receive Invoice for the Purchase Order

When we receive the invoice for the PO, the exchange rate from USD to EUR has changed to 0.9.

Therefore, the invoice value of 50 USD is converted into 55.56 EUR.

This results in an exchange rate difference of 15.17 EUR (55.56 ‚Äì 40.39 = 15.17 EUR) debited under transaction key KDM in the Accounting document.

Material Price Analysis (CKM3N) also receives the exchange rate difference in a separate line as below:

 

4. Create a Production Order

Now that the required raw material RM124 has received into inventory, the plant 1210 is ready to starts its manufacturing of the product SG224-DEMO. For this, a production order (1011288) of 50 PC of SG224-DEMO is created:

According to bill of materials (BOM) and routing of SG224-DEMO, the following raw materials and production activities are required to manufacture 100 PC of SG224-DEMO:

5. Goods Issue, Time Confirmation, and Goods Receipt for the Production Order

In the actual manufacturing process, variances can happen in the consumption of components (input materials) and activities. In  this example, we confirm more working time for activities Setup (activity type 3), Machine (1), and Labor (11) than planned.

Due to the Backflush indicator, with the time confirmation above, the withdrawal (goods issue) of input materials (RM124) is posted automatically.

Since the final operation 0020 has the Automatic Goods Receipt indicator flagged, confirmation of 0020 also results in a full delivery (goods receipt) of 50 PC into inventory.

6. Settle the Production Order

Since 1011288 is an event-based production order, full delivery automatically triggers the order settlement. We can check the production variances in app Order Costs Details - Event-Based:

The total production variance is 407.08 EUR, split into different variance categories, reflecting the causes of the variances. The variance is debited as a net loss in P&L account under transaction key PRD in the Accounting document.

Note: The above-mentioned features are related to Production Accounting (3F0) and are not the main goal of this blog. You can find more details in SAP help (https://help.sap.com/s4_ce_prd_acc).

Now we can look at how the goods receipt and production variance of SG224-DEMO is captured in Material Price Analysis (CKM3N):

  • Goods receipt of 50 PC is evaluation as 341.00 EUR (50 PC multiplied by standard price 6.82 EUR) as shown in Preliminary Valuation column.
  • The production variance of 407.08 EUR collected from order settlement is shown as Price Difference.

7. Create a Sales Order and Outbound Delivery

Following the completion of production of SG224-DEMO, we create a sales order (1516) to sell 20 PC of SG224-DEMO at the price 10 EUR/PC to a customer. Then we issue the goods to the customer with an outbound delivery document (80000286):

The goods issue is updated in Material Price Analysis (CKM3N) under Consumption as follows:

Before the actual costing settlement, the sales quantity of 20 PC is still evaluated using standard price 6.82 EUR (6.82 EUR * 20 PC = 136.40 EUR).

Note that the profitability segment 106851 is derived from the sales order item. It combines all the relevant attributes of the sales order, including sales order ID, sales org, distribution channel, customer group, ship-to party, etc.

8. Settlement in Actual Costing

At the period-end close, we execute the Actual Costing run in CKMLCP (Edit Actual Costing Run), also known as costing cockpit.

Note: Before the settlement in Actual Costing, make sure you‚Äôve run the WIP Quantity Calculation job in Schedule Inventory Accounting Jobs for accurate WIP revaluation in Actual Costing. Also, remember to calculate actual activity cost rates in the Actual Cost Rate Calculation - Cost Centers app. These steps are not demonstrated in this example.

In the settlement step, the system does the following:

1. Determine any price and exchange rate variances of lower-level materials (RM124 in our example).

In the Cumulative Inventory line, Actual Value (90.56 EUR) is a sum of preliminary valuation value, price difference and exchange rate difference. The actual price 0.45 EUR/PC of RM124 by dividing the actual value (90.56 EUR) by the cumulative quantity (200 PC).

Note that according to the ratio of consumption quantity/cumulative quantity (50 PC/200 PC), the production of SG224-DEMO only shares 1/4 of the total difference (5.39 EUR + 15.17 EUR = 20.56 EUR), that is 5.14 EUR (20.56 EUR/4). 

2. Roll the variances through to higher materials (SG224-DEMO) that used the lower-level materials.

In Material  Price Analysis of finished goods SG224-DEMO, 5.14 EUR from lower material (RM124) is rolled up, divided into 1.35 EUR of price difference and 3.79 EUR of exchange rate difference.

3. Calculate actual price (periodic unit price).

Actual price is calculated for each of the materials as shown above: 0.45 EUR/PC for RM124 and 15.06 EUR/PC for SG224-DEMO. These prices can reflect the actual cost more accurately, as all goods movements and cost fluctuations within the period are considered.

4. Allocate the cumulated variance (and cumulative actual value) to consumption and ending inventory.

As shown in screenshots of points 1 and 2, the cumulative differences are allocated to consumption and ending inventory in proportion to the quantity as follows:

MaterialCumulative Difference (EUR)Consumption (EUR)Ending Inventory (EUR)
RM12420.56 (= 5.39+15.17)5.14 (=20.56*1/4)15.42 (=20.56*3/4)
SG224-DEMO412.22 (=408.43+3.79)164.89 (=412.22*2/5)247.33 (=412.22*3/5)

With that, consumption and ending inventory are revaluated as shown in Actual Value column.

9. Post Closing Documents

Now that the cumulative differences are allocated and actual values of consumption and inventory are revaluated, we can post the closing entries to ACDOCA (Universal Journal) to adjust the consumption (e.g. COGS for SG224-DEMO) and ending inventory values, so that the relevant P&L accounts and B/S accounts are updated.

To do that, select both Revaluate Material and Revaluate Consumption when executing Post Closing in the costing cockpit (CKMLCP),

The Post Closing step is executed successfully.

In Material Price Analysis, you don‚Äôt see much changes except the Period Status is updated to Closing Entries Completed and the price control of the materials is converted from S (Standard Price) to V (Periodic Unit Price), meaning the material stock has been revaluated at the actual PUP price in the period.

Taking SG224-DEMO as an example, let‚Äôs look at what closing journal entries are posted by Actual Costing (you can jump to these journal entries by choosing Closing Document on the screen). These journal entries are classified with the type ML (ML Settlement). ML stands for Material Ledger and Actual Costing is traditionally a part of it.

In the consumption (COGS) revaluation journal entry 4700000034, we can see that the adjustment value of 164.89 EUR together with the COGS splits by cost component. Notice the Account Assignment Type is EO (Profitability Segment). With the profitability segment 106851, as we saw earlier in the consumption line, the sales order item-specific attributes, such as Product Sold, Sales Order, Sales Org, and Customer, are also kept in the line items. Thanks to that, we can get a margin analysis report with the finest granularity to be shared later.

In the other journal entry 4700000034, by filtering product SG224-DEMO, we can see the following items sorted by transaction key:

  • BSX (Inventory)

Item 44 is a total difference (price and exchange rate differences) of 247.33 EUR is debited to the inventory account, indicating a value increase of the material stock.

  • GBB (COGS)

Item 47 shows a total difference (price and exchange rate differences) of 164.89 EUR is debited to the COGS account.

  • KDM (Exchange Rate Differences)

Items 11 is the exchange rate differences received from lower material RM124. Items 46 and 49 are those credited to the exchange rate difference accounts.

  • PRY (Price Difference)

Item 10 is the price difference received from lower material RM124. Items 45 and 48 are those credited to the difference accounts.

Additionally, the items 44, 46 and 45, representing inventory revaluation line in CKM3N, are automatically reversed in the subsequent period (009/2025) as shown below:

This brings the stock of period 009/2025 back to standard price. Meanwhile, the price differences and exchange rate differences assigned to ending inventory in period 008/2025 are carried over into the beginning inventory of period 009/2025.

In this way, the system ensures the actual cost of the beginning inventory of the new period equal that of the ending inventory of the previous period.

Note: Price difference for the consumption of 164.87 EUR in period 008/2025 is not reversed.

That concludes the example showing how Actual Costing collects differences of all goods movements along the period, calculates a more reliable actual price, and allocates the differences into consumption and material stock.

10. View Produce Profitability

Following the posting of consumption revaluation, you can view updated COGS in margin analysis report, such as Product Profitability Review Booklet:

Here, for 20 PC of the product SG224-DEMO sold, the total COGS 301.29 EUR is a sum of preliminary valuation (136.40 EUR) and the consumption revaluation (163.37 EUR) by Actual Costing as you can see from the CKM3N screen in step 8.

By navigating to the line items, we can confirm that the closing journal entries posted by Actual Costing are considered in the COGS. 

Additional Features

This section briefly talks about the Actual Costing features that are not covered above.

Multiple Currencies and Valuations

Actual Costing supports inventory valuation in multiple currency types (company code currency, group currency, and if configured, functional currency) and valuation views (legal valuation, group valuation) achieved by parallel ledgers.

Valuated Quantity Structure

Valuated quantity structure shows the scaled receipt quantity of the actual input materials/activities in a hierarchical view.

The following screen shows the production structure of SG2024-DEMO from the above example, including raw materials and activity types valuated in both preliminary valuation and actual valuation.

The valuated quantity structure helps you analyze the differences roll-ups by showing all the price differences from the lower level to the top material level.

Note this view is dynamically generated without persisting in database, therefore the system performance might be slow in case of many hierarchy levels.

Cost Component Split (CCS)

Cost component split breaks down costs into cost components such as material, various production activities, and overheads. Actual Costing shares the same cost component structure as in product cost planning.

As you can see in Material Price Analysis, the columns such as Direct Material, Material Overhead, Personnel Time, Machine Time, Set-up Time, and Production Overhead represent the cost components. Their values are determined based on the G/L accounts (cost elements) assigned to each component.

SAP is re-designing the cost component split feature with the concept of Universal Component Breakdown. We will explain this feature in detail when available in Actual Costing.  

Activity Consumption Analysis (CKM3A)

Actual Costing also revaluates activity types of each cost center by using the actual cost rates that are determined in Actual Cost Rate Calculation - Cost Centers  app (KSII).

In the following screen of Activity Consumption Analysis (CKM3A), we can tell that for in plant 1210 in period 008/2025, the cost center 12101301 consumes 1.25 hours of activity type 3 (Setup Production) for manufacturing SG224-DEMO with production order 1011288. In reality, there are more production orders and manufactured products.

The Preliminary Valuation column shows the activity valued with plan cost rates (378.88 EUR/hour) maintained in Manage Cost Rates ‚Äì Plan or imported from SAP Analytics Cloud. The Actual Value column shows the activity cost valuated at the actual cost rates (388.89 EUR/hour) calculated in KSII at period end.

In the closing journal entries, the price difference is credited to the cost center (transaction key PRL Activity Price Difference)  and debited to the material price account.

Other Fiori Apps

Additional Fiori apps are available for multiple-material view, for example, Display Actual Costing Result F6073. See help documentation for more info.

Technical Implementation:

To use Actual Costing in SAP Cloud ERP, the scope item 33Q must be activated. With 33Q activation, the following are active by default for the relevant plants:

  • Actual cost component split
  • WIP revaluation at actual costs
  • Activity consumption update in actual quantity structure is active and is taken into account upon price determination. 

To access the relevant apps, users must be assigned with a role that contains the following business catalogs:

  • SAP_FIN_BC_IA_AC_PER_ACT_PC (Actual Costing - Periodic Activities) for apps such as Edit Actual Costing Run (CKMLCP).
  • SAP_FIN_BC_IA_FACT_MPRC_PC (Inventory Accounting - Material Price Analysis) for apps such as Material Price Analysis (CKM3N, aka CKM3)
  • SAP_FIN_BC_IA_AC_REP_PC (Actual Costing - Reporting) for apps such as Display Actual Costing Result (F6073).
  • SAP_FIN_BC_IA_OM_REP_PC (Actual Costing - Activity Reporting) for apps such as Activity Consumption Analysis (CKM3A)

Master Data Preparation

The materials subject to Actual Costing settlement are those with price control S (standard price)and price determination 3 (single/multi-level) as below:

Note: By default, price determination 2 (Transaction-Based) is used in material creation.

Related Info

For more deep-dive topics in Actual Costing, for example, WIP revaluation, not distributed and not allocated values, see FAQ Note https://me.sap.com/notes/3617837 (FAQ of Actual Costing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud) with concrete examples.

We will continuously update the Note or publish blogs for other in-depth topics in Actual Costing, such as fallback logic for actual price calculation, account determination for closing journal entries, and available configuration activities. You are very welcome to leave comments under the blog.
